items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Board of Trustees are authorized pursuant to Section 21113 of the California Vehicle Code to set forth conditions and regulations pertaining to the operation and parking of vehicles or bicycles, or the conveyance of animals upon the grounds of all Foothill and De Anza campuses.  
	 
It shall be the duty of the members of District Police Departments and such persons as are authorized by the Chief to enforce all of the provisions of the Regulations and California Vehicle Code in a manner authorized by the California Education, Penal and Vehicle Codes. 
	 
The Parking and Traffic Regulations were last revised and approved by the Board of Trustees in 2004. This update reflects current parking fees, permit types, special parking designations (e.g. electric car charging stations at De Anza), new parking lot rental procedure and fee schedule, along with general language and procedural revisions.
	 
Submitted by:
Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services
Additional contact names:
Ronald Levine, Chief of Police
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Vice Chancellor of Business Services Kevin McElroy recommends approval of the revised Parking and Traffic Regulations.
items.item_text: Parking & Traffic Regulations
items.item_text_raw: 3. Parking & Traffic Regulations

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
California Education Code sections 81450 – 81460 provide that the governing board of a community college district may sell, donate, or dispose of personal property if it is unsatisfactory and no longer suitable for school use.
	 
At De Anza College, as several departments and programs move from their temporary locations back into the newly renovated Advanced Technology Center for Winter Quarter classes, some of the furniture currently used will be replaced with new (see attached list, 5 pages).  It has been determined that the furniture is at end of life and is unsatisfactory and no longer suitable for District use. At the end of Fall Quarter instruction and prior to the holiday break the furniture in the existing spaces will need to be removed and some of the spaces will be reconfigured to accommodate Winter Quarter classroom requirements. 
	 
Purchasing Services staff met with De Anza campus representatives and Plant Services representatives to coordinate a plan to remove the furniture and dispose of it. In an effort to best utilize District resources and expedite the process in the most efficient manner, Purchasing Services recommends that, in the best interest of the District and in the most charitable and environmentally sound way practical, the furniture be sold, donated, recycled or disposed of on-site.   Purchasing Services will attempt to donate usable furniture first to other public entitles, then to charitable organizations.  If the furniture cannot be donated then Purchasing Services will sell the furniture.  Any remaining furniture will be recycled or disposed of.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Interim Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to arrange for the sale, donation, recycle, or disposal of the furniture in accordance with the procedures set forth in Education Code sections 81450-81460.
items.item_text: Sell, Donate, Recycle or Dispose of Surplus Furniture
items.item_text_raw: 4. Sell, Donate, Recycle or Dispose of Surplus Furniture

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Board is requested to approve a compensation agreement reached between the Foothill-De Anza Community College District and the Administrative Management Association.
	 
The District and Administrative Management Association have met and conferred and agree on the 
2013-14 compensation for administrator employees. The terms of this settlement include the following:
	 
Salary adjustment of 2.07% (equivalent to the state-provided 1.57% COLA plus 0.5%)
	 
Terms: The salary adjustment shall be retroactive to July 1, 2013.  The adjustment shall commence as soon as possible following the Board approval, but not later than the November 2013 pay period, which shall also include the retroactive pay.
	 
Attached are corresponding changes to the AMA Salary Schedule.
	 
Also attached are corresponding 2.07% changes to the Executive Administrator Salary Schedule which, in accordance with Executive Contracts, is adjusted equal to any salary increase adjustment(s) granted to District Administrator Salary Schedules.
	 
Submitted by:
 Dorene Novotny, Vice Chancellor of Human Resources & Equal Opportunity x6211
Additional contact names:
 Suzanne Pfeiffer, Director of Human Resources x6109
Is backup provided?
 Yes
items.item_recommendation: Dorene Novotny, Vice Chancellor of Human Resources and Equal Opportunity, recommends approval.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Description of Proposed Lease. This agreement for lease of unneeded space to construct an on-site branch is in response to student interest, particularly financial aid recipients, in having banking options that are currently not available to many De Anza students.  US Bank has been chosen because of their unique experience and commitment to establishing mini-branch banks with services to students on 33 college campuses across the country. De Anza students will benefit from free checking (4 years) and other banking services, with access to a wide network of ATM’s.
	 
The proposed lease is for approximately 350 square feet of space located in the college bookstore at De Anza College which is not needed for academic activities and within which US Bank will build out and operate a full service branch bank to meet the needs of interested students and staff. A copy of the Lease Agreement is attached. 
	 
Explanation of Lease Rate and Methodology to Determine Fair Market Value. The  base rent is $10,000 per year enhanced by several tangible and intangible factors which increase the value to the District, and which more than satisfy our understanding of fair market value in these unique circumstances. The District/College and US Bank are in agreement that the annual compensation, in addition to the services/benefits provided to the college community by the US Bank on-site branch, in exchange for the modest square footage of space provided in the bookstore facility reasonably equates to fair market value for the space being leased. In addition, the $2,500 annual student scholarship being provided by the bank, the financial literacy workshops planned for students given by bank staff and the fact that US Bank will operate the branch at its sole cost significantly enhances the tangible and in-kind value being provided by US Bank in exchange for use of the space in the De Anza college bookstore.
	 
Code Compliance. The three-week public notice required by Education Code section 81378.1(b) has been given in a newspaper of general circulation.
	 
Submitted by:
President Brian Murphy  x8705
Additional contact names:
Letha Jeanpierre, Vice President Finance and Educational Resources x8976
Donna Jones-Dulin, Associate Vice President of  Finance and Educational Resources x8209
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: President Brian Murphy recommends approval/ratification of the USB Lease Agreement for 5 years with option for 2 two-year contract extensions

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Student trustee Anita Adams was unable to attend the regular Board meeting of September 9, 2013, due to illness.  As stated in Education Code §72024(d):
	 
A member may be paid for any meeting when absent if the board, by resolution duly adopted and included in its minutes, finds that, at the time of the meeting, he or she is performing services outside the meeting for the community college district, he or she was ill or on jury duty, or the absence was due to a hardship deemed acceptable by the board. The compensation shall be a charge against the funds of the district.
	 
Included for adoption by the Board is a resolution verifying the circumstances of student trustee Adams’ absence as required by Education Code Section 72024(d).
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor 
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Linda Thor recommends approval of the resolution authorizing student trustee Adams' absence from the September 9, 2013, Board of Trustees meeting.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis
	 
The Accrediting Commission for Community and Junior Colleges (ACCJC) reaffirmed De Anza College's accreditation in January 2012 with the requirement that the college prepare a Follow Up Report addressing the three recommendations of the comprehensive evaluation team.  Following submission of the report in October 2012, the ACCJC sent an evaluation team to the college to conduct a follow up visit. The ACCJC's review of De Anza College's Follow Up Report and the report of the visiting team resulted in a request that the college submit a second Follow Up Report by October 15, 2013, focusing on the recommendation concerning the college's mission (Recommendation 1). 
	 
The requested report is attached for review and approval of the Board of Trustees.
	 
Submitted by:
Brian Murphy
Additional contact names:
Mallory Newell, Marisa Spatafore
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: De Anza College President Brian Murphy recommends approval of the Follow-Up Report.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Foundation for the California Community Colleges (FCCC) negotiates special pricing on behalf of the California Community Colleges for software and hardware products.  The District participates in the Microsoft Campus Agreement plan through the FCCC, which allows us to purchase an annual site license agreement for Microsoft products at a substantially reduced price based on our FTE faculty/staff count, less the percentage of faculty on overload teaching status and reduced by the number of faculty and staff on leave. The average cost savings compared to the normal Academic or Select license is approximately 60-70%.  It provides a 20% reduction in the license cost from the retail group purchase price.  ComputerLand of Silicon Valley is the vendor that administers this program.  The cost to the district, for this year, is $84,195.00 based on a Foothill College cost of $32,487.00 and a De Anza cost of $51,708.00. This is the third year of a three-year contract the FCCC has with Microsoft.
	 
The agreement also allows our employees to purchase selected Microsoft applications for their personal use at a substantially reduced price through the FCCC.  
	 
Because the purchase is through the FCCC there is no need to participate in a formal bid process.  The term of the contract will be October 1, 2013, through September 30, 2014.
items.item_recommendation: Vice Chancellor Joseph Moreau recommends purchase of the Microsoft Campus Agreement from ComputerLand of Silicon Valley for the amount of $84,195.00
items.item_text: Microsoft Campus Agreement Renewal (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 18. Microsoft Campus Agreement Renewal (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District currently relies on an outside vendor for the maintenance and support of its Fujitsu 9600 PBX telephone system and peripherals including AVST Voice Mail (XpressCare) and the Amcom E911 and Site Alert System.  The telephone system is scheduled for replacement in late 2015 or early 2016.  Therefore, telephone maintenance services on the current system are required until the replacement system is installed and operating.
 
The District Purchasing Services Department prepared bid documents and incorporated technical specifications jointly written with ETS staff in order to invite bids for a one-year contract to support its Fujitsu 9600 PBX telephone system and peripherals.  The contract is renewable for up to four additional one-year periods at the District’s option until this telephone system is replaced. 
 
The bid was advertised on August 16, 2013 and August 23, 2013.  The “Invitation to Bid” was sent to two (2) vendors, as well as posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  On September 13, 2013, Purchasing Services staff received two bids and publicly opened and read the bids.  The bid received from American Telecom Services, LLC did not conform to the bid requirements in Section 3.01 Bidding Process, which states ”Bidder must complete, sign and return the entire bid package and two (2) photocopies of the entire bid package and deliver them in one sealed box to District Purchasing Services…”.  This is not an immaterial error therefore making the American Telecom Services, LLC bid non-responsive. Furthermore, even if the bid were considered responsive it would not have been the lowest bid received. The second bidder, Altura Communication Solutions met all of the mandatory requirements of the bid specifications to provide the necessary maintenance and support of the PBX system.  The pricing submitted is shown below:
 
 
Altura Communication Solutions
American Telecom Services, LLC
Annual Maintenance and Support Cost for year one and year two
$98,795.00 
$100,000.00
 
Altura Communication Solutions currently provides the same telephone maintenance and support services and its bid price of $98,795.00 reflects a 1.04% savings and is firm for two years.  ETS “A” Budget will fund the annual telephone maintenance and support services.
	 
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey
Additional contact names:
Joe Moreau, Sharon Luciw, Lisa Hocevar, Dawn Allshouse
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Reject the bid submitted by American Telecom Services, LLC as non-responsive and authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to execute an agreement with Altura Communication Solutions Not To Exceed $98,795.00 in accordance with Invitation to Bid #1651 contract prices, terms, and conditions for a one-year term effective November 1, 2013 with an option to renew for up to four additional one-year periods.
items.item_text: Authorization to award contract pursuant to Invitation to Bid #1651 for Telephone Maintenance & Support (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 19. Authorization to award contract pursuant to Invitation to Bid #1651 for Telephone Maintenance & Support (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The terms of the community members serving in the following positions on the Measure C Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee will expire at the end of this calendar year:
Taxpayers association representative
At-large representative
Business organization representative
Foothill-De Anza auxiliary organization representative 
In accordance with the committee's bylaws, the following process and timeline will be used to appoint new members to fill the vacancies:
October 4 - November 15:  Applications will be solicited from appropriate local groups
November 18 - November 29:  Chancellor or designee will review all applications
December:  Chancellor or designee, following consultation with the Board president, will make a recommendation to be considered at the January 13, 2014, Board of Trustees meeting
January 13, 2014:  Board of Trustees will consider appointment of the recommended committee members
Submitted by:
Kevin McElroy
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
On June 18, 2012 the Board of Trustees rejected all bids for Bid 1348-420 District Office Building Renovation.  That project consisted of three primary scopes of work; (1) renovation of the District Office Building, (2) renovation of existing modular trailers to house District staff during the 11-month renovation period, and (3) site work for additional modular trailers. Only two bids were received and the lowest responsive bid price received was 14.8% over the construction budget.  The board was advised that District staff would revise the scopes of work and rebid the work in the future. The site work for the modular trailers was completed in Project #105 and the District Office Building Swing Space project to renovate the trailers was awarded on May 13, 2013; that work is now substantially complete and District staff will relocate to the modular trailers while construction on the District Office Building is underway.
					 
Additionally, at its March 4, 2013 meeting, the Board of Trustees accepted a list of fourteen (14) contractors who met all of the prequalification requirements as the only direct contractors who are “prequalified” to bid on the Measure E Project #420 – District Office Building Renovation.
					 
The District Office Building Renovation project consists of an interior renovation of existing space including flooring and finishes; removal and disposal of old materials that is of not required for school purposes pursuant to Education Code 81656; bathroom renovations; mechanical, electrical, plumbing infrastructure improvements; fire alarm improvements; and telecommunications upgrades. The project will also include some site work in the adjacent areas.  Cody Anderson Wasney Architects prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department.
					 
Bid #1348-420R was legally advertised on August 13 and August 20, 2013.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the Daily Pacific Builder, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Eight (8) of the fourteen (14) pre-qualified contractors attended the mandatory job walk on August 27, 2013 and six (6) of those contractors submitted bids.  Bids were publicly opened and read on September 18, 2013 at 3:00 p.m. by Purchasing Services. The bid results are shown below:
					 
 CONTRACTOR
 BASE  BID          AMOUNT
 Alten Construction, Inc.
 $2,938,000
 D. L. Falk Construction, Inc.
 $2,959,000
 Calstate Construction, Inc.
 $2,999,555
 S. J. Amoroso Construction Co., Inc.
 $3,047,000
 James R. Griffin, Inc.
 $3,074,000
 Zolman Construction and Development, Inc.
 $3,560,000
					 
The lowest responsive and responsible bidder is Alten Construction, Inc. (Alten). Alten successfully completed projects for other public agencies including the modernization of the Chinese Immersion School at De Avila in San Francisco, the College of Marin Indian Valley Transportation Technology Complex modernization, and the Merritt College Learning Center Library renovation.  Furthermore, Alten and its listed subcontractors have each signed the “Agreement To Be Bound” and the “Agreement of Contractors” of the Project Stabilization/Construction Careers Agreement between the District and the Santa Clara & San Benito Counties Building and Construction Trades Council.  
					 
The bid price of $2,938,000 as submitted by Alten exceeded the construction estimate of  $2,600,000 but is within the expected bid range. The project will be funded with a combination of Measure E and District Capital funds.
Submitted by:
  Gina Bailey, Int. Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
  Charles Allen, Art Heinrich
Is backup provided?
  No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to award a contract pursuant to Bid Document #1348-420R, in the amount of $2,938,000 to Alten Construction, Inc.
items.item_text: Award a contract pursuant to Bid #1348-420R District Office Building Renovation - $2,938,000 (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 22. Award a contract pursuant to Bid #1348-420R District Office Building Renovation - $2,938,000 (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis: 
	 
This revision is required to implement Bond list changes that are needed to adjust and prioritize approved project scopes and funding at Foothill and De-Anza College.  
	 
De-Anza Budget Transfer #39 includes the following actions:
Transfer $114,076.10 of $131,409.10 interest earned in Quarter 4 Fiscal Year 2012/2013 to Project 274, Combined Site Improvements to augment the project budget to match CMDM budget and construction contingency, and $17,333 to Project 248, Campus Drive to pay back the previous borrowing (Reference DA BT #33).
Transfer $4,500 from Project 203, Baldwin Winery & East Cottage “Historic Renovation” into Project 248 to pay back the previous borrowing (Reference DA BT #33). 
Transfer $16,743.94 from Project 256, Campus Center Phase II into Project 248 to pay back the previous borrowing (Reference DA BT #33).  Project 256 is financially complete.
Note that current budget for Project 274 will have an additional funding source of $85,924 due to PG&E Rebates (Checks 37-38 Series I and Checks 16-17 Series II) not shown here.
Foothill Budget Transfer #41 includes the following actions:
Transfer $131,409.11 of interest earned in Quarter 4 Fiscal Year 2012/2013 to Project 162, Parking and Circulation.
Transfer a portion of budget ($200,000) from Project 120, Smithwick Theater and ($200,000) from Project 199, Foothill Program Contingency to Project 141, Exterior Painting and Bird Remediation.  This transfer will augment Project 141 (previously underfunded) to cover original scope of project.
Submitted by:
Charles Allen
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Bernata Slater, Tom Armstrong, Donna Jones-Dulin
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_text_raw: 24. Measure C Project List Revision with Foothill Budget Transfer #41 and De-Anza Budget Transfer #39 (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Fire Alarm System Replacement Phase III project is the final phase of upgrading the existing fire alarm system at the Foothill Campus.  The project replaces wiring infrastructure that connects the separate buildings and updates older fire alarm system elements to produce a single, integrated alarm system. 
	 
On August 29, 2011 the Board of Trustees authorized the implementation of a procedure that prequalifies prospective bidders for public projects.  Before concluding a prequalification process, Purchasing Services reports the results to the Board of Trustees and at that time the board can either choose to accept the list of contractors who met all of the prequalification requirements as the only contractors who are prequalified to bid on the project or cancel the prequalification procedure for the particular project. 
	 
Prequalification #1638-174 was legally advertised On May 8, May 15, July 18 and July 25, 2013.  The legal ad was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Two (2) C-10 Electrical Contractors submitted the completed questionnaire to the District by the August 15, 2013 due date.
	 
Purchasing Services staff and the Foothill College Measure C Bond Team, have determined that there are an insufficient number of prequalification applicants to competitively bid the Fire Alarm System Replacement project, Phase III. Therefore, Purchasing Services staff and the Foothill College Measure C Bond Team recommend that Prequalification #1638-174 be canceled.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Interim Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Charles Allen, Art Heinrich, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Cancel Prequalification #1638-174, Fire Alarm System Replacement Phase III.
items.item_text: Prequalification of C-10 Electrical Contractors for the Fire Alarm System Replacement Project, Phase III at Foothill College (Prequalification #1638-174) (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 25. Prequalification of C-10 Electrical Contractors for the Fire Alarm System Replacement Project, Phase III at Foothill College (Prequalification #1638-174) (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The De Anza Nursing Program tests its students' application of theory, assessment, and skills in a safe environment that does not jeopardize an actual human patient.  The nursing instructors train student nurses by giving those students actual clinical experience utilizing training manikins (patient simulators) in a hospital room setting to facilitate basic and advanced life support training. The Nursing Program currently has one adult and one infant manikin.
 
The Nursing Program is updating and expanding its curriculum by adding a fully integrated recording and debriefing system to the clinical experience.  The system will allow instructors to remotely control the manikins using custom and pre-programmed scenario software and monitor students while they practice emergency treatment using manikin patients. A patient simulator manikin recording and debriefing system captures the live simulation.  After the training scenario is completed, students and instructors can review the recorded sessions in a remote debriefing room.  The recording and debriefing system will fully integrate with manikin patients in two simulated hospital rooms.  The program requires one additional adult manikin, software, accessories, equipment, warranty, and training to create two simulated hospital rooms with manikin patients. 
 
The District Purchasing Services Department prepared bid documents and incorporated technical specifications jointly written with De Anza College staff for the purchase of the Nursing Patient Simulation System for the Nursing Program.  The technology equipment required to fully integrate and operate the manikins in the teaching environment are included in Invitation to Bid (ITB) #1473.
 
ITB #1474 was advertised in the San Jose Post Record on August 9, 2013 and August 16, 2013.  The ITB was sent to three (3) vendors, as well as, posted on “BidNet” at  www.govbids.com.  Purchasing Services staff publicly opened and read the bids on September 6, 2013 at 2 PM.  The bid results are shown below:
 
 
CAE Healthcare
Laerdal
Grand Total
$106,643.35
$121,645.00
 
De Anza staff evaluated the METIman Nursing Patient Simulation system proposed by CAE Healthcare and determined that it does meet or exceed the ITB specifications and the program requirements.  In addition, Purchasing Services contacted six (6) references provided by CAE Healthcare who all identified that they were satisfied with CAE Healthcare as a vendor and verified that its proposed METIman patient simulators worked well in a teaching environment.  As provided in the bid instructions, the award will be made to the responsive and responsible bidder who offered the lowest grand total on the bid forms. Therefore, the lowest responsive and responsible bidder is CAE Healthcare.
 
The project is funded from Nursing Alumni Association and Measure C FF&E.  The Nursing Alumni Association will fund certain costs such as on-site installation, an extended warranty, and a manikin loaner repair service that are not allowed by Measure C; that portion of the bid is a total of $9,500. The Measure C budget for the project is $235,000 and the aggregate total costs of ITB #1473 and ITB #1474 is well under that amount.
	 
Submitted by:
 Gina Bailey, Interim Director of Purchasing Services, ext 6165
Additional contact names:
 Letha Jeanpierre, Edward Breault, Jean Burke, Dawn Allshouse
Is backup provided?
 No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to issue a purchase order to CAE Healthcare in the amount of $106,643.35 in accordance with Invitation to Bid #1474.
items.item_text: Award a contract pursuant to Invitation to Bid #1474 - Nursing Patient Simulation System - $106,643.35 (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 26. Award a contract pursuant to Invitation to Bid #1474 - Nursing Patient Simulation System - $106,643.35 (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District Purchasing Services Department prepared bid documents and incorporated technical specifications jointly written with De Anza College staff for the purchase of a nursing patient simulation system and related audio/video equipment required to complete a fully integrated recording and debriefing system for the De Anza College Nursing Program. Invitation to Bid (ITB) #1474 is for the nursing patient simulation system and this ITB #1473 is for the required audio/video equipment.
 
ITB #1473 was advertised in the San Jose Post Record on August 9, 2013 and August 16, 2013.  The ITB was sent to three (3) vendors, as well as, posted on “BidNet” at  www.govbids.com.  Purchasing Services staff publicly opened and read the bids on September 6, 2013 at 3 PM.  The bid results are shown below:
 
 
Signal Perfection Limited
Presentation Products, Inc. dba Spinitar
Grand Total
$102,036.62
$126,560.72
 
As provided in the bid instructions, the award will be made to the responsive and responsible bidder who offered the lowest grand total on the bid forms. The lowest responsive and responsible bidder is Signal Perfection Limited.  De Anza staff evaluated the audio/video system proposed by Signal Perfection Limited and determined that it meets the ITB specifications.  Signal Perfection Limited has successfully provided multimedia and audio/visual equipment and services for several District projects and it is also the District’s current vendor for the multimedia equipment and installation contract through 2016.  
 
The project is funded in its entirety from the Nursing Alumni Association and Measure C FF&E.  However, only Measure C FF&E will fund the cost of the audio/video system.  The Measure C budget for the project is $235,000 and the aggregate total costs of ITB #1473 and ITB #1474 is well under that amount.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Interim Director of Purchasing Services, ext 6165
Additional contact names:
Letha Jeanpierre, Edward Breault, Jean Burke, Dawn Allshouse
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to issue a purchase order to Signal Perfection Limited in the amount of $102,036.62 in accordance with Invitation to Bid #1473.
items.item_text: Award a contract pursuant to Invitation to Bid #1473-Audio/Video System for the Nursing Patient Simulation System- $102,036.62 (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 27. Award a contract pursuant to Invitation to Bid #1473-Audio/Video System for the Nursing Patient Simulation System- $102,036.62 (ACTION)
